    Installation Instructions

    Last updated on 2025-10-19 | Edit this page

    Prerequisite

    You‚Äôll need basic familiarity with opening applications, downloading files, and copy-pasting commands.
    No prior experience with programming or Git is required.

    Setup Overview

    These steps prepare your computer for the workshop.
    They work on Windows, macOS, and Linux ‚Äî look for tabs marked
    ü™ü Windows only or üêß macOS/Linux only where steps differ.

    We‚Äôll use Visual Studio Code (VS Code) as the main workspace and terminal.

    Step 1 ‚Äî Install Visual Studio Code

    Download and install VS Code for your operating system:
    üëâ https://code.visualstudio.com/Download

    After installation, open VS Code once to complete setup.

    Callout

    What to expect

    You should see the Welcome screen with tabs for ‚ÄúStart‚Äù and ‚ÄúExtensions.‚Äù

    Add Helpful Extensions

    From the menu, choose View ‚Üí Extensions (or press Ctrl+Shift+X / Cmd+Shift+X).
    Search for and install these extensions:

    • Python (by Microsoft) ‚Äì enables Python coding and linting
    • GitLens ‚Äì adds Git history and collaboration features
    • Git Graph ‚Äì shows branch and commit history visually
    • Excel Viewer ‚Äì view CSV and Excel files
    • JSON Editor ‚Äì improve JSON readability
    • ü™ü Start git-bash ‚Äì adds a Git Bash terminal inside VS Code (Windows only)

    Set up the Integrated Terminal

    1. Install Start git-bash (from the Extensions Marketplace).
    2. Go to Terminal ‚Üí New Terminal.
    3. Click the ‚ñº next to +, choose Select Default Profile, and select Git Bash.
    4. Open a new terminal tab ‚Äî you should see bash on the right.
    1. Go to Terminal ‚Üí New Terminal.
    2. Click the ‚ñº next to +, choose Select Default Profile, and select bash or zsh.
    3. Open a new terminal tab to verify the shell name on the right.

    You‚Äôll use this terminal for all remaining steps.

    Step 2 ‚Äî Install Git

    Download Git for Windows from https://gitforwindows.org/.
    During setup:
    - Set Editor to Visual Studio Code
    - Set default branch name to main
    - Leave other options at default

    This also installs Git Bash, which you‚Äôll now use inside VS Code.

    Git is usually pre-installed.
    If not, install with your package manager or from https://git-scm.com/downloads.

    Step 3 ‚Äî Check Terminal and Git

    Checklist

    Verify your setup

    In VS Code‚Äôs terminal, type:

    BASH 

    date
git --version

    ‚úÖ You should see today‚Äôs date and a Git version number.
    Keep this terminal open for the next step.

    Step 4 ‚Äî Install Python using uv

    We use uv to install Python and manage project environments automatically.

    Run this in your VS Code terminal:

    BASH 

    curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

    When it finishes, close and reopen the terminal, then verify:

    BASH 

    uv --version
uv python --version
    Callout

    ü™ü Tip for Windows users

    You don‚Äôt need PowerShell or separate installers ‚Äî everything runs inside VS Code‚Äôs Git Bash.

    Step 5 ‚Äî Download Course Files

    Download the practice data:
    üëâ https://github.com/carpentries-incubator/better-research-software/raw/refs/heads/main/learners/spacewalks.zip

    Unzip spacewalks.zip to an easy location (e.g., Desktop).
    In VS Code, open the folder (File ‚Üí Open Folder‚Ä¶) to see the files in the Explorer panel.

    Step 6 ‚Äî Set up Your Project Environment

    In the VS Code terminal:

    BASH 

    uv init

    Edit the new pyproject.toml so it looks like:

    TOML 

    [project]
name = "spacewalks"
version = "0.1.0"
dependencies = ["pandas", "matplotlib"]

    Then install and run the code:

    BASH 

    uv sync
uv run python spacewalks.py
    Discussion

    Test your setup

    If you see a plot or printed output, everything works!

    Step 7 ‚Äî (Optional) Set up GitHub

    Checklist

    Optional: Save your work online

    1. Create a GitHub account: https://github.com/
    2. Follow the SSH setup guide: https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh
    3. Test your connection:

    BASH 

    ssh -T git@github.com

    ‚úÖ You should see a greeting message from GitHub.

    Key Points
    • Use VS Code as your coding workspace and terminal.
    • Git manages version control and integrates with VS Code.
    • uv simplifies Python installation and environment management.
    • You‚Äôre now fully set up for the workshop!

    This version should paste cleanly and render correctly within the Carpentries Workbench build system (sandpaper::build_lesson()) without breaking from nested code blocks.
